content:
###Summary of angle sizes

Angle type| Angle size (in degrees) 
- | - 
Acute | Between $0^\circ$ and $90^\circ$
Right |  Exactly $90^\circ$ 
Obtuse |  Between $90^\circ$ and  $180^\circ$
Straight |  Exactly $180^\circ$
Reflex | Between $180^\circ$ and  $360^\circ$
Complete |  Exactly $360^\circ$

###Right angles

A right angle is a $90^\circ$ angle.  A right angle  is in the shape of a perfect corner, like the corner of a rectangular sheet of paper.  Below is an example of a right angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: One ray extends to the right of the vertex. Another ray extends upward. A square at the vertex connects the rays to represent a perfect corner, or a right angle.

content:
###Straight angles

A straight angle is a $180^\circ$ angle.  A straight angle looks like a straight line.  Below is an example of a straight angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A straight line with a half circle on top and at the center of the line to represent a straight angle.

content:
###Acute angles

An acute angle is an angle whose degree measure is less than $90^\circ$.  Below is an example of an acute angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

When we compare an acute angle to a $\blueD{\text{right angle}}$, we can see that an acute angle is less than $90^\circ$.  

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A ray extends to the right of the vertex. Another ray extends to the right and upwards from the vertex. A curved line connects the rays to represent an angle, in this case an acute angle, which has a degree measure less than 90 degrees.
The acute angle from above set inside a 90 degree angle, called a right angle. Comparing the angles, the acute angle has a smaller degree of measure than the right angle.

content:
###Obtuse angles

An obtuse angle is an angle whose degree measure is greater than $90^\circ$ but less than $180^\circ$.  Below is an example of an obtuse angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

When we compare an obtuse angle to a $\blueD{\text{right angle}}$, we can see that an obtuse angle is greater than $90^\circ$.  


[[☃ image 2]]

When we compare an obtuse angle to a $\greenD{\text{straight angle}}$, we can see that an obtuse angle is less than $180^\circ$.  


[[☃ image 3]]

*Want to learn more about angle types?  Check out [this video](/v/acute-right-and-obtuse-angles).*

options.alt: A ray extends to the right of the vertex. Another ray extends up and to the left of the vertex. A curved line connects the rays to represent an angle, in this case an obtuse angle, which has a degree measure of greater than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees.
The obtuse angle from above with a 90 degree angle, called right angle, set inside it. Comparing the angles, the obtuse angle has a greater degree of measure than the right angle.
The obtuse angle from above set on a straight angle, or straight line. Comparing the angles, the obtuse angle has a smaller degree of measure than the straight angle.

content:
###Reflex angles

A reflex angle is an angle whose degree measure is greater than $180^\circ$ but less than $360^\circ$.  Below is an example of a reflex angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

When we compare a reflex angle to a $\purpleD{\text{straight angle}}$, we can see that a reflex angle is greater than $180^\circ$.  

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A ray extends to the right of the vertex. Another ray extends down and to the left of the vertex. A curved line connects the rays to represent an angle, in this case a reflex angle, which has a degree measure of greater than 180 degrees but less than 270 degrees.
The reflex angle from above set on a straight angle, or straight line. Comparing the angles, the reflex angle has a larger degree of measure than the straight angle.

content:
###Complete angles

A complete angle is a $360^\circ$ angle.  A complete angle has both rays pointing the exact same direction.  That is because we've turned a full circle from the first ray. Below is an example of a complete angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A ray extends to the right of the vertex. Another ray also extends to the right of the vertex, exactly on top of the first ray. A curved line that forms a full circle connects the rays to represent an angle, in this case a complete angle, which has a degree measure of 360 degrees.

content:
###Practice set 1: Identify angles

[[☃ graded-group-set 1]]

*Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/angle_types).*

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1A
gradedGroups.content:
**Is the following angle acute, right, obtuse, or straight?**

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A ray extends from the vertex towards between 3 and 4 o'clock. A second ray extends from the vertex towards 5 o'clock. An arc connects these two rays.

hint.content:
The shown angle measures less than $90^\circ$.

**Therefore, it is an acute angle.**

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1B
gradedGroups.content:
**Is the following angle acute, right, obtuse, or straight?**
 
[[☃ image 1]]


[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A ray extends from the vertex towards 8 o'clock. A second ray extends from the vertex towards 1 o'clock. An arc connects these two rays.

hint.content:
The shown angle measures greater than $90^\circ$ but less than $180^\circ$.

**Therefore, it is an obtuse angle.**

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1C
gradedGroups.content:
**Is the following angle acute, right, obtuse, or straight?**
 

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A ray extends from the vertex towards between 9 and 10 o'clock. A second ray extends from the vertex towards between 12 and 1 o'clock. A square at the vertex connects the rays to represent a perfect corner.

hint.content:
The shown angle measures $90^\circ$.

**Therefore, it is a right angle.**

content:
###Practice set 2: Angles in diagrams and images

[[☃ graded-group-set 1]]

*Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/recognizing-angles).*

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2A
gradedGroups.content:
**What type of angle is the angle highlighted in green below?**

[[☃ radio 1]]


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: The letter K. Inside the top angle of the letter K, a ray extends from the vertex towards 12 o'clock. A second ray extends from the vertex towards between 1 and 2 o'clock. An arc connects these two rays.

hint.content:
The angle formed by the highlighted part of the letter $K$ is less than $90^\circ$; it does not open as wide as the shape of a corner of a sheet of paper.  

**The angle highlighted in green is an acute angle.**

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2B
gradedGroups.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the angles in the diagram are obtuse angles?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A six-pointed star figure made up of six equal-sized diamonds. The center point is labeled with the letter O. From the center point, the 4 points of the top diamond are labeled O, B, C, and D. Moving clockwise to the next diamond in the star figure, the 4 points are labeled O, D, E, and F. Moving clockwise again to the next diamond in the star figure, the 4 points are labeled O, F, G, and H. Moving clockwise again to the next diamond in the star figure, the 4 points are labeled O, H, I, and J. Moving clockwise again to the next diamond in the star figure, the 4 points are labeled O, J, K, and L. Moving clockwise one last time to the next diamond in the star figure, the 4 points are labeled O, L, A, B. Four angles are shown inside the star figure. Angle one connects line segments BO and BC. Angle two connects line segments OD and OF. Angle three connects line segments LO and LK. Angle four connects line segments GH and GF.

hint.content:
An *obtuse angle* is an angle whose degree measure is greater than $90^\circ$.  

Let's compare the four angles in the diagram to a right angle.

$\purpleC{\angle{2}}$ and $\blueD{\angle{4}}$ do not open as wide as a right angle.  So, they are not obtuse angles.  


$\redC{\angle{1}}$ and $\greenD{\angle{3}}$ open wider than a right angle.  So they are obtuse angles. 

**$\redC{\angle{1}}$ and $\greenD{\angle{3}}$ are obtuse angles.**

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2C
gradedGroups.content:
**What type of angle is $\angle{A}$?**


[[☃ image 1]]



[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A parallelogram with one angle labeled A. One line extends from the vertex of angle A towards 1 o'clock. A second line extends from the vertex of angle A towards 9 o'clock. An arc connects these two lines.

hint.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

When we compare a right angle to $\angle{A}$, we can see that $\angle{A}$ is greater than $90^\circ$.  

**$\angle{A}$ is an obtuse angle.**

options.alt: A parallelogram is shown with one angle labeled A. A right angle is drawn on top of angle A so that one ray of the right angle completely overlaps one side of the parallelogram and the other ray of the right angle intersects angle A. Angle A opens wider than the right angle.

content:
###Practice set 3: Drawing angle types

[[☃ graded-group-set 1]]

*Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/drawing-right--acute--and-obtuse-angles).*

gradedGroups.title: Problem 3A
gradedGroups.content:
**Drag the vertex of the angle to place the vertex at point $\text{A}$.**  

**Drag another point on the angle to make one of the rays go through point $\text{B}$.**

**Make the other ray go through one of the unlabeled black points to create a straight angle.**  
*The arc symbol near the vertex indicates the angle being measured.*

[[☃ interactive-graph 2]]

hint.content:
Here is the way to make a straight angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

It's a straight angle because its measure is $180^\circ$.

options.alt: A straight line with three points on it. The first point is unlabeled, the second point is labeled A, and the third point is labeled B. An unlabeled point that is not on the line appears to the upper left of the straight line.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 3B
gradedGroups.content:
**Drag the vertex of the angle to place the vertex at point $\text{A}$.**  

**Drag another point on the angle to make one of the rays go through point $\text{B}$.**

**Make the other ray go through one of the unlabeled black points to create a right angle.**  
*The arc symbol near the vertex will show the right angle symbol when the angle is correct.*  
  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
Here is the way to make a right angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

It's a right angle because its measure is $90^\circ$.

options.alt: A right angle with a vertex labeled A. One ray includes a point labeled B. The other ray includes an unlabeled point. An unlabeled point appears to the left, inside of the right angle.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 3C
gradedGroups.content:
**Drag the vertex of the angle to place the vertex at point $\text{A}$.**  

**Drag another point on the angle to make one of the rays go through point $\text{B}$.**

**Make the other ray go through one of the unlabeled black points to create an acute angle.**  
*The arc symbol near the vertex indicates the angle being measured.*

[[☃ interactive-graph 2]]

hint.content:
Here is the way to make an acute angle.

[[☃ image 1]]

It's an acute angle because its measure is less than $90^\circ$.

options.alt: An acute angle with a vertex labeled A. One ray includes a point labeled B. The other ray includes an unlabeled point. An unlabeled point appears below the acute angle.
